question: Question_02_(c)
statement:
\textbf{Short-Answer Questions}. Question 1-3 are short-answer
questions. Put your answer in the box provided. \textbf{Simplify your
answer as much as possible}. Full Marks will be awarded for a correct
answer placed in the box. \textbf{Show your work}, for part marks.

The first two terms in the Maclaurin series for $x^2\sin(x^3)$ are
$ax^5+bx^{11}$, where a and b are constants. Find the values of \emph{a}
and \emph{b}.
sols:
Recall the MacLaurin series for sin(\emph{x}) is given by

\[\sin(x) = x - \frac{x^3}{3!} + \ldots\] so

\begin{align*} 
x^2\sin(x^3) & = x^2\left(x^3 - \frac{x^9}{3!} + \ldots\right) \\
& = x^5 - \frac{x^{11}}{3!} + \ldots
\end{align*} so

\[a = 1, b = -\frac{1}{6}\]
hints: Work with the MacLaurin series for $\sin x$ first, then manipulate it.
